I can't believe that happened, I've never been treated so poorly by someone who runs a business. Never come here. The food is alright, but over priced and not thaaat good. If you want good food and better prices, go to Zapata around the corner. I'll never come back to La Tortilla, this place is only still in business because of their location.
author: Trenton C.

description:
While my review is specifically for Friday night, I have to start by saying over the last couple of years La Tortilla has been on a downward spiral. Friday night sealed the deal, however, and I will never be back. I ordered two shrimp tacos and a soda ($10!) I received two tacos with pinkish-grey salad shrimp, no seasoning, and clearly undercooked/raw tortillas. You would think if they have "tortilla" in the name, they would know how to at least do one of those right.

I shoveled one of the gross, bland tacos down because I knew I would later be drinking and had to have something in my stomach. I wasn't thrilled about eating the second taco, but figured I had to in order to get through the night. So I bit into the taco and found a PLASTIC TWIST-TIE for their tortilla bag inside of my food, which completely ruined the already terrible meal.

I took the twisty-tie to the counter and let the woman preparing food know what was up. I didn't complain, I waited for her other customers to be gone so I wouldn't embarrass her, I didn't even ask for my money back. I just wanted to let her know, so they wouldn't serve someone else plastic in their food. The only response I got was complete confusion. Very disappointing. 

If you want Mexican food that tastes like plastic and has plastic inside of it, choose La Tortilla.
author: Matt B.

description:
La Tortilla must live in a flavorless world where spices and marinades don't exist, because I've never had a burrito so bland. How could someone be so cruel to such a magnificent creation?

Fairly new to the neighborhood and having already tried Zapata, I figured I should give La Tortilla a shot. It is not a mistake I'll be repeating.

I ordered to-go and the people behind the counter were reasonably nice and fast. Oddly, I wasn't given any containers for the salsa bar, and none were to be found near the bar itself, so I had to return the register. The people behind me had to do the same.

Despite having the makings of a perfectly delicious burrito -- steak, hot and mild salsa, guacamole, cheese, rice, beans, etc. -- the result was decidedly not. The meat had zero flavor and the salsas and guac accounted little more than runny consistency. Even adding spicy salsa I picked up from the salsa bar couldn't give La Tortilla's burrito any semblance of enjoyable flavor.

Burrito enthusiasts beware, this place will crush your dreams.
author: Scott L.

description: Nice employees who make me smile.  Yummy food that fills me up for a low price.  Who could ask for more?
author: Cynthia B.

description:
scary!! 
After the chips & spicy salsa I'm too nervous to give anything else a try. 

The chips tasted like chips . No complaint there. I was offered the spicy salsa instead of regular, so I thought, "sure why not."  BIG mistake!!  
The taste was slightly odd, but against my better judgement and right mind (I was starving) I ate it any way. 
A few moments later my stomach got unhappy and my body rejected the salsa..4 times! A day later..still rejecting.
I also had a side of the green salsa..maybe the combo was bad?? I don't know..I just suggest trepidation when it comes to the spicy salsa for sure.

Good Luck!
author: Brandyy S.

description:
I can't do this any more.

I keep trying to enjoy this place but it just doesn't work.

And it's not me -- it's you, La Tortilla. You're not good enough.

The meat isn't ANYTHING enough. The sauces and salsas are bland. At least the people who work there are nice.

But the prices -- oh god, the prices -- of this filler-grade food is insult on top of injury.

In one of the greatest burrito cities in the world, your taqueria can't get by on a nice location.

Can't do it. Not gonna do it again. Goodbye, La Tortilla.

Recommended? = No. Just go to one of the Can-Cun locations already or read burritoeaterdotcom instead to find some other burrito place.
author: Chris R.

description: These are by far the best burritos I've had in San Francisco. The menu could do a better job describing the items but this is a wonderful little place. The seating by the window is prime for people watching and their horchata is fantastic!
author: Laura D.

description:
Andale! Andale! Arriba! Arriba!
Theez eez Speedy Gonzales, the fastest mouse in all Mehico...also the most poleetically incorrect. I will have my muchacho Slowpoke Rodriguez play the guitar while I seeng...

La cucaracha, la cucaracha!
Doesn't want to travel on,
Because she hasn't,
Oh no, she hasn't
Marijuana for to smoke.

Si, theez are the true Ingles words to "La Cucaracha". No keeding. But you don't need reefer to enjoy La Tortilla, Senor. Oh no. Eeet eez bueno enough for an andale-andale meal in the heart of the Castro. Lots of orange and yellow in theez place. Muy bright since the hombres around here...they like the bright colors, si.

I had the Chimichanga deener for $7.25. Eeet come with dos chimichanga folded over like deep-fried peegs in a blanket. Only there eez no peegie...eeet eez cheecken. Eeet come with salad, black beans and rice. Muy grande deesh for the dinero, Senor. Sabroso, too...if you are cheep foodies like me and Slowpoke.

Slowpoke, he like the muy grande Burrito here. Only he no like how brown the guacamole look sometimes. Oh I don't mind 'cuz eef I get da runs, I just go to the banos real fast. Andale! Andale! Arriba! Arriba!

FOOD - 4 stars...eez no mal...no better Mehican alimentos in all the Castro, Senor...si, Slowpoke?
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...bright and tight...like the rest of the Castro
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they serve like the senoritas in my village
TOTAL - 4 stars...fastest Mehican in all the Castro
author: Ed U.

description: really gross, dirty, surly.  we'd be a lot better off with chipotle or another coffee shop in this spot
author: jon s.

description: There are way better options out there if you are in the mood for Mexican. Food is ok, atmosphere is ok, prices are reasonable, and service kinda sucks. People who work there could use a smile once in a while, avoiding being grumpy at customers all the time.
author: Silvia P.

description:
I keep meaning to review this place. 

I love coming here for a mushroom quesadilla, especially on rainy days in the Castro. I'm not a vegetarian, and I tend to prefer my quesadillas with meat, but for some reason their mushroom quesadilla keeps me coming back. They're so cheesy and delicious. 

I love their flan as well. It's almost like creme brulee.
author: Christine A.

description: BEST sopes I've ever had in my life. Sorry mom. I'm serious. Try them. Have them with pollo asado. Mmmmmmmmmmm
author: Alex H.

description:
This review is from 1/14/12, just finishing it now.

I Got the Chorizo Breakfast Burrito $5.50 & their special chile rellano de mango special side order $4.50 to go, was craving some Mexican food this morning.  The food was decent but not the best I've ever had hence the 3 star rating.  Haven't been back since.
author: Arthur Z.

description: I happened upon this place in the Castro neighborhood on a Sunday afternoon and am so glad I did! It was not very busy when I went in, maybe one or two other customers. The two ladies working were extremely friendly and the food tasted so fresh! It was lovely to get to sit in the window seat and watch people walk by (probably jealous of my tasty dinner!) I was visiting San Francisco from Minnesota, so I haven't been around fantastic Mexican food, but I really thought this place was an incredible value and tasted fantastic! I got a chicken fajita burrito and was very impressed!
author: Laura M.

description:
La Tortilla's motto should be "Give me your hungry, your tired, and your drunk." Stumbling out of Badlands or Toad Hall, it is a beacon of light before trekking home. The ladies of La Tortilla make any end to a drunken Castro night a wonderful one. Friendly and smiling, their broken-English charms the pants off any drunk.

I usually get nachos and slather fresh pico de gallo all over it with a few jalepenos on the side. Nachos are good. Burritos are okay (try some of their vegetarian ones, including the tofu one). And their tacos are pretty tasty as well.

Nothing too fancy. Just your regular Mexican food joint that you can become a regular at if you drink in the Castro 7 days a week.

Thanks La Tortilla!
author: Mike N.

description:
I think the food here is great. It's everything I look for in quick Mexican food - great taste, fresh, hot.

I love that they steam the tortillas before serving them. Rice cooked perfectly (moist) and beans are tender and flavorful. Carne asada (grilled beef) is just right - not tough or overcooked.

I like other menu options like tamales, too. 

Chips & salsa included with meal at no extra charge - bottled sodas (including Jarritos) available, as well.
author: Jason B.

description:
Alright, so I would never think to try this place when I'm sober... but sometimes after a night of gay-binge-drinking, heaping amounts of delicious Mexican food sounds just right.

I think the food is really good, or at least I eat it all. Maybe it is only good because I am drunk when I eat it... either way it is still good.

I always order to go. Try the mushroom quesadilla. I've made mushroom quesadillas for myself at home and I always thought it was pretty güero of me... but believe me, they are delicious.
Also, the chicken mole azteca burrito is sooo good and it is enough to share. 

Overall, it is good late night food, but it's no Taqueria Cancun.
author: Russell Allen E.

description:
So I'm driving home around 11 last night when it occurs to me that I never ate dinner and just might pass out during the long, dark drive down 280.  Fortunately for me, La Tortilla was still open and well lit, so I swung a U-Turn and headed inside.

Despite the relatively late hour on a Wednesday, La Tortilla's staff seemed wide awake, the place was clean and the other clientele appeared to be normal members of society (i.e., not selling drugs, buying drugs or eating food out of the garbage).

I got my standby burrito fix -- grilled chicken with black beans and guacamole -- and it served my purpose just fine.  The burrito was well wrapped, the chicken wasn't overcooked and the flavor was pretty darn good.  The guac was just adequate, but I find that it often is at  counter service places like this one.

So in reference to previous reviews, I guess I qualify as one of those white guys who liked La Tortilla and am appreciative of cleanliness generally.  And while I'm not scared of the Mission, I don't buy into the theory that all good burritos originate there (or that all Mission burritos are good).  

Anyhow, give this place a whirl some late night.  It'll get you through a long drive if nothing else.  :-)
author: Geoff D.

description:
This review is overdue! Me and My friend Raf, were walking through the streets ( reason: Halloween) and decided to grab a bite and of course to use the bathroom (lol). It was so crowded and decided to enter this little Latin restaurant! The line was ridiculously long but man did it smell amazing! I decided to go for it! 

As I approached the ordering counter, a young lady quickly and very politely, took my order, which I order nachos.

I quickly got my order and attended my needs! 
After much needed rest and time to chill for a bit, I took a bit of my order, and man, damn those nachos were finger licking good!!! I am not too much of a eater and especially because I have a sensitive stomach, but wow! 

If the nachos are awesome, I can't wait to go back to taste the other items in the menu!!!!
author: Liz L.

description:
My chicken quesadilla looked like a titanic wreck, but still tasty. I helped myself to the salsa verde, which was good but very very hot! Add with caution!

Quite a small place with slightly less seats than Zapata around the corner. A little messier and when the busser starts cleaning up tables you'll smell their cleaning spray. It quickly goes away, but what a killer to one's appetite!

UPDATE: I could smell the "cleaning spray" on my second visit and it just turned me off completely to this place. I think they're killing 'bugs' in the kitchen when you smell that stuff. Gross. I don't think I'll ever go back.
author: Rina W.

description: Large burritos with hot rice and fresh ingredients. Breakfast burritos are a great value. My favorite quick bite on the go in the castro
author: Zack B.

description: This is seriously my favorite burrito in San Francisco (although my friends in the mission give me shit for saying that). I may not be a traditionalist, but I love getting a burrito with melted cheese and chicken mole (plus, of course, rice, beans, salsa, and whatever else I want to add in). So ooey gooey delicious. I love that I can customize with whatever fillings I want as they're making it, rather than the binary rice-beans-meat-salsa, and optionally sourcream-guac-cheese upgrade that a lot of places have - not much room for customization. Another bonus - free freshly fried chips and a salsa bar! The horchata is great, too. This place is a great value, and my go to for nights when I'm starving after a workout.
author: Caitlin J.

description: Terrible tacos. Com'on I've had way better for really cheap.  This is suppose to be authentic?  There was no flavor on the chicken tacos that I ordered.  If you wanted lettuce of tomatoes or any item that normally goes on any tacos there's an extra charge for each item.  The people weren't very friendly or attentive at all.
author: Trynh K.

description:
Discovering and walking through every neighborhood of San Francisco during our vacation, we deciced to stop and enter in this "cantina mexicana" while we were being "surprised" by the Castro! 

In Belgium, it is hard to find this type of restaurants and we were really enthousiastic when we saw it!

Notincing the "la tortilla" written in a colorful way we decided to see how it was Inside and the result was: it was a great idea to get in! 

Beside the fact it was hard to get understood, we spent a nice moment there, enjoying tacos and burritos! Big enough, fair prices, tasty and nice/casual atmosphere: all the ingrédients were pr
We strongly recommand you to stop by and eat one of their burritos! They are just ... great and tasty!
author: Miranda M.

description: Damn..damn.. Damn.. I came here every week after hitting the bars. Tonight though the employees were handling both the cash and the tortillas. Money is filthy. I won't be going back now.
author: Bill L.

description: The woman at the register must really hate her job. I couldn't finish my huge quesadilla, so I asked for a to-go box and and she give the worst "eye roll" attitude. Come here only if you're blacked out drunk so that you won't remember the horrible experience. The portions are big, the options good, and the food is edible.
author: Pedro S.

description:
One day, I had went to the City. My b/f agreed to pick me up downtown and we would go to a gay bar. Him being a straight boy and me being a "T" who hadn't mentally left the boy behind. We decided to go here.

I had chicken mole and we kissed. We talked about what he was about to embark on. He seemed so shock that we weren't the only men in there who were in love.

We went to Badlands later and I drank 4 cocktails and 2 shots in 20 minutes.

That night I threw up the chicken mole I consumed. But you know what, it was to die for! Thank you making the last meal before I descended into perpetual drunkness...the best ever.

I sometimes hit this when I am in the mood for the Mexican food.
author: Lana P.

description: This place blows. Food stinks. People who work here are diablos. Never eating here again.
author: Lydia C.

description:
Before realizing there are 4,000+ San Francisco restaurants waiting to be tried, including tons of burrito joints, I used to go to La Tortilla all the time. Comparison to how things used to go down vs. today, when I made it back to officially yelp:

                             ~2005       ~2010
Tortilla:                 Flour         Wheat
Beans:                 Pinto         Black
Rice:                     Yes           No
Salsa:                   Mild           Mild

Added the salsa bit because, well, some things never change.

Burrito was good, loved that tofu ranchero, wish they weren't charging extra for the lettuce, especially sans rice.

It was A-OK to be back. No need to ever return.
author: Jason B.

description: A great value before heading to see a screening of Mommie Dearest at the Castro Theater. Chicken black-bean burrito with a tich of hot sauce hit the spot. Two of us split one and it was the perfect amount of food for our pre-theater/;pre-dinner munchies.
author: Michael G.

description: Decent for a quick meal, but nothing special. The food could use a bit more flavor and the service could be friendlier.
author: Brett B.

description: Pretty good food at a cheap price. The only downfall is not a full bar for some margaritas but still worth it to stop in for lunch or any other time.
author: BP R.

description:
La Tortilla serves up the standard Mexican food fare, and I can't say that I've ever wandered in here during regular daylight hours. With that in mind, its brightly lit interior and colorful walls attract me like a moth to a flame when I've been partying hard and have thus worked up an appetite that only Mexican food can satisfy. The line (which is almost guaranteed at the late hours I wander into here) actually moves pretty fast, and I think my friends bring me in with them because they know I'll use my charms to chat us up a table, so I've never really had to wait to be seated to enjoy my meals, either. From what I can recall, the sopes are particularly good, if you happen to like sopes. 

Bottom line: It's fast Mexican food and my midnight wanderings on Castro wouldn't be as fun without stopping in for a quick bite at La Tortilla. Mexican food is comfort food for me, so I'll take it however I can get it for nostalgic purposes.
author: Liz P.

description: I was in the Castro with my friend and we were looking for a good place to eat, we decided to try here. The food was pretty good. Chips and salsa were also pretty good. If you're in the Castro looking for a good Mexican food place. I suggest going here.
author: Anthony F.

description: I've stopped at this location for lunch a few times. The Super Burrito costs $8.49 after tax. Decent place to eat, parking can be an issue
author: Joe A.

description: Last time i was already annoyed with the service, today they started nice enough, but when i asked for the salsa they usually have, they said that they didnt have it. it was 10 passed midnite on a friday, get your sh** together. i think it is sad that this taqueria is the only late night place in the castro, cuz the customer service is aweful!!!!
author: Paul C.

description: This place has been my go to Mexican food fix after a night of dancing in the Castro.  Surprisingly, the food is pretty good (I am pretty picky since I am half Mexican). I always get their super burrito and it never ceases from hitting the spot. I have been to many restaurants in the Mission and am happy to say that this place certainly is better than many of them. Plus, they are open super late and take cards. I would definitely recommend this place to any Mexican food aficionado who happens to be in the Castro.
author: Gabe E.

description: This place is HORRID. I am pretty sure that everything comes out of a can. If you are DRUNK you might like it because you will forget you ate here.  Other than the canned, bland and sloppy food, the 2 women that always seem to be behind the counter here must go visit the wizard in order to obtain a brain. They don't understand the concept of customer service. I had to ASK for chips 2 times and she just stared at me as if she was bludgeoned on the head and spun around 10 times. Eventually I got chips. 6 chips to be exact. As I sat down in the empty restaurant on the hard, food crumb ridden seats, I  noticed that my tostada had no cheese on it. When I told them that they forgot the cheese on my Tostada the lady said "oh no, cheese is not included". CHEESE IS NOT INCLUDED?! What mexican restaurant on the PLANET charges extra for cheese?! Don't eat here. If you want REAL mexican food, walk 6 blocks to the mission, put salsa on your finger and eat that, just do anything as long as you skip this place..
author: Superbucky N.

description: Surprisingly enough, their burritos taste a lot better cold and having been refrigerated for two days. So, for all the drunk idiots like me who are too wasted to finish their burrito at 2am-- toss that shit in the fridge, forget about it, and then stumble upon it after 4:20pm and your munchie crisis will be solved.
author: Jerome C.

description: Open late, takes credit cards, cheap. My veggie burrito was pretty decent and unlike a lot of shitty taquerias in the city, the burrito wasn't cold. 3 stars.
author: Kristen F.

description: When they tell you their spicy chicken meat is spicy, BELIEVE IT. When they tell you their spicy salsa is spicy, BELIEVE IT. Outside of these two, the food really wasn't that memorable. Chips were a little subpar. Tasted like they were a day or two old and should have been tossed out already. I got the regular burrito. I liked that everything was fresh, but there was any distinctive flavor that made me ever want to come back. Price was ok for the quality and workers were friendly.
author: John N.

description:
Boring, bland, flavorless burritos. 

Granted, that's all I've ever tried there, but I can't understand how a burrito can have so many ingredients ("marinated" chicken, salsa, "hot" sauce, cheese, rice etc) and taste like absolutely nothing. 

I gave this place a few chances because I live nearby and wanted it to be good, but nope. La Tortilla = La Boringsville
author: Cee D.

description:
Meh...I've had waay way better almost anywhere in Southern California and a lot of NorCal Mexican restaurants. I shared a super burrito, a large heated flour tortilla with spicy chicken, cheese, black beans, rice, guacamole. The filling just wasn't hot enough, it was lukewarm and the cheese didn't melt. The burrito had no flavor...not spiciness or garlic, it was disappointingly bland. Complementary tortilla chips were a plus. Snapple was on the menu, but they didn't have it so I got Orangina... They had a variety of Mexican drinks. 

The salsa bar was great in theory, but all of the salsa basins were empty so I couldn't try any! The one open booth had lots of gross crumbs and pieces of lettuce on it. The busboy wiped down the table but didn't wipe down the booth or chairs, it was gross and fast food like. Maybe it was an off time, with so many Mexican options available in SFO I wouldn't settle for this again.
author: Stephanie S.

description: cheap! but definitely sub par. i got a cheese quesa for i think $3.80 and it was good, but this would not be my first choice for mexican food...the only reason i would go back is cuz its conveniently by the castro muni station!
author: Christie B.

description: They spent more time talking to each other than listening to what I was ordering.  Food is okay, but nothing to write home about.  Better than Zapata.
author: Bob R.

description:
Yeah, I am still on my veggie burrito kick. And this place did not steal my heart. 
They had a good selection of vegetarian burrito's and I went with just the basic one. Maybe that was my mistake but judging from other's reviews, probably not. 
It was bland, didn't taste like much. Thats pretty much all I have to say about it. Boring, yes. Just like the burrito.
author: Kelley D.

description:
Long story, but interesting!

I came in here after a long night of drinking and dancing.  A woman behind us in line was talking to the cashier in Spanish, asking if she could order a beer.  Now we had probably been in line for about 5 minutes at the max and it was already 1:58AM and they are not allowed to sell alcohol after 2PM.  The guy running the cash register tells the woman that he's not allowed to serve beer after 2PM which is the law.  The woman and the man go back in forth in Spanish and then she starts yelling at him in English that she's been standing in line for over 10 minutes and she should be able to get a beer.

After holding up the line, the line starts to proceed out the door.  She is still yelling at the guy in the cash register and the rest of the staff just ignore her.  People who have ordered food start to leave cause they don't want to deal with her.  After a while, I finally decide to speak up and say something.  Now I'm pretty sure I could have phrased it a little better, but I was quite buzzed and basically told her that he wasn't going to give her a beer so just live with it and besides she was only in line for like 5 minutes.

We then proceed into a shouting match back and forth.  She says I don't know her and that her dad owns the place and she'll have the f'ing place shut down.  I tell her that go ahead and call him then and shut the place down.  Although I don't know if her dad really owns the restaurant or she was just BSing, but a drunk daughter shouldn't shame her family business by treating the customers poorly.  The shouting continued back and forth.  She finally started throwing out racial slurs at me like "slanty-eyed."

Now you would think as a fellow minority, people do know how it feels to be at the brunt of ignorance as well as to be shot at with racial slurs.  It makes no sense to me when minorities contain the same ignorance and prejudice that we are faced with on a daily basis.

Anyways, my friend then proceeds to record her on his new blackberry, hoping that she might be the newest internet meme.  She notices and walks over, crushes his phone and breaks it.  After more shouting, some other people in line finally decide to join in and help out.  In the end of it she came over to our table, flip it over and I end up with tacos all over my clothes.  As she proceeds out, I call her a couple of names which won't be repeated but was offered some nice thanks for speaking up from other customers.

I guess this is what I get for trying to be a nice guy and wanted to stick up for the cashier, although I could have picked my battles more carefully.

To top it off (which is why they are getting only 1 star) the staff did NOTHING to help stop the conflict or kick her out originally.  They all just sort of ignored her and pretended she wasn't there.  After I got mine and 2 friends tacos on myself, the management didn't even offer to give me a refund or to remake our tacos.

PLUS the tacos SUCKED! I had two bites and noticed that it had zero flavor.  I wouldn't come back here again to support a business (if she really was the daughter of the owner) that treats their customers and employees with disrespect.  Plus the food blows!

Also an FYI, this place has repeatedly had huge violations from the health inspectors.  Check http://www.cleanscores.com/rest-170611-La-Tortilla-San-Francisco
author: Kameron K.

description: I've been here twice and each time the service has been terrible!  I'm pretty easy to please but when someone lies to me about having vegetables I can SEE on the counter, and then serves them to the next person, even I get a lil miffed.  I've worked in the food industry and I know it can be stressful, but basic courtesy is a must.  Even if you have terrible food, you can keep customers by having great service.  For La Tortilla, they get an F on both counts.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Do you LOVE *meh* Mexican food? How about $8 steak burritos? If your in the mood for unexciting culinary experience, then this is the place for you.

There are lots of options, but nothing is fantastically exciting. I had the steak burrito...nothing to write home about. It did it's job though: nourishment.
author: Misha F.

description: We got the super burrito and ask them to cut it in half.  Chicken, refried beans, cheese, sour cream and a side of guacamole with free chip.   The open till 2am on Sunday it across from the 24 hour Walgeens.   Friendly service but the salsa bar was really low but thats becausewas almost 2am.
author: John F.

description: La Tortilla is always the best hangover food. I respect the workers here because they have to deal with a whole bunch of drunkies while making amazing food. I love this little mexican restaurant, especially the front windows that are great for people watching. This place is always very clean which is amazing! I love that they maintain their restaurant. The food like I said is amazing and there is this one lady who has amazing hazel eyes! Anyways, fast great friendly. Pretty much all you want!
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
Gross gross gross!!! Yes, perhaps if one is drunk, this food may seem to hit the spot.. but otherwise?? oh me thinks not! 

It's a consensus amongst all of us in the workplace... do NOT go to La Tortilla! They overcharge for bad burritos that just don't make the cut.. the meat, the tortilla (oh, the irony), the beans, the sauces... almost an insult to the icon which is the San Francisco burrito! 
Prices are ridiculously high here, so I've sworn against this place now. 

Seriously, the to-go food in this neighborhood is so lacking! I swear I'm going to start going to Subway!
author: Sf Momm Y.

description:
The food here is...extremely "meh." I ordered a vegetarian super burrito, and absolutely nothing stood out about it. The rice was bland, the beans were bland, the cheese tasted like mozzarella, and the tortilla tasted like the kind you'd get at Safeway. *I*, a gringo, can make a better burrito than this joint can, and that's saying something. At least I know how to add more flavour to food. To add insult to injury, this burrito was lukewarm, especially in the middle. Lukewarm burrito = I THINK NOT. It wasn't even hot enough to melt the cheese! Cold cheese in a burrito = FAIL. 

Atmosphere sucked, and it looked as though some of their fillings had been sitting out there a while, especially the refried beans. Now, I'm a big refried bean fan, but if you're going to serve refried beans, maybe you should prevent them from getting a crust on them. Just saying. 

Thank god this burrito was only around $6, otherwise I would've been even more upset. 

Not to mention, I got a stomachache soon after having eaten it. I will not be a repeat customer of La Tortilla. This did NOT taste like a SF taqueria. This tasted like a fake taqueria that opened in some dinky town in Middle America that has no Latin@ presence. 

 I'm shocked that I saw that many people walking into the restaurant, considering how many better places there are in San Francisco.
author: Finn G.

description: A great place to grab some Mexican food at the Castro. Staff is friendly. The price is right. Their salsa is awesome!
author: Ana C.

description: Such a pathetic attempt at Mexican food. If you like mushy bland food that tastes the same as anything/everything you'll love this place. This place really should clear its space and make way for something better.
author: Matt V.

description: First and foremost, the staff is super nice. That said , the food is edible. The food is voided of any flavor. I live for Mexican food, and this was a major let down. Super cheap but I rather pay more and enjoy my food.
author: Rick A.

description: A trip to San Francisco would be incomplete without a stop at  a taqueria for one of SF's signature foods.  I'd been to taquerias in the Mission on previous visits so I had a comparison point of reference.  Arriving here rather late on a Sunday evening after a sentimental stroll through Noe Valley where my brother-in-law and sister-in-law used to live, I was hankering for a snack before taking the Muni back to my hotel.  Ducking in here I felt safe ordering a couple of beef tacos.  They tasted OK, but the meat was kind of tough and because the peppers and onions were so moist, the tortilla got soggy and was a mess to pick up and eat.  Had I ordered to go, my tacos would have been wrapped and unwrapping to eat would have been a lot easier.  It was also my first time trying an horchata, a puree of rice and water along with vanilla and cinnamon, and it was pretty good.
author: Sean M.

description:
The other night, Aaron G and I were roaming around the Castro looking for a bite to eat prior to meeting some friends at Given. Hmmm, where to go? Sausage Factory? No... too heavy. Escape from NY Pizza? No... Aaron had pizza for lunch. What could we eat that was light and filling and wouldn't take to much time? Well hello there La Tortilla. 

Looking at their expansive menu, I realized that I had the craving to stuff my mouth full of pork, so I ordered the super taco. The taco was made to order, and while it wasn't taco truck quality, it hit the spot. For less than five dollars, I had a super taco, a small bowl of chips and a cantaloupe aqua fresca. The salsa bar gives you a three different salsas to choose from: mild, medium and hot. 

La Tortilla is a great value when you want a little snack between meals. Oh, and Aaron mentioned something about it being exactly like Mexico au Parc in Soma.

P.S. Broccoli Burrito? Really? I haven't tried it and I'm sure it's a great veggie option, but aren't the beans enough to make you toot?
author: Chum L.

description: Food was delicious, and they give you quite a bit of it. Very friendly staff, which I appreciated. Only complaint is the place is super packed inside.
author: Cole G.

description:
Judging from the facade, I did not expect to find a Mission-style burrito place inside. It looked very chain-like from the sidewalk, but the carnitas burrito I ordered was quite good and the ordering protocol was exactly the same as on Mission Street: Line up, specify tortilla type, bean type, meat type, yes or no on rice, spicy or mild salsa, super or regular.

The thin red salsa from the salsa bar was especially good. I might try to buy it by the pint in the future.

One super burrito and one regular burrito with guacamole came out to just over $19, so somewhat pricey but in line with what one would expect in this neighborhood.
author: Hunni B.

description:
I've tried the tostada and I've tried the super burrito.  Both times I was pleasantly surprised, much better than I expected.

The meat and toppings are excellent, the service was friendly and quick , and the layout was clean and very simple.

I don't know how you could give this place less than 3 stars, considering all the slimeball-taquerias that barely compare to this spot.

Check out this spot for sure if you're in the neighborhood.
author: L J.

description: SOOOOO yummy. Cute location and good food. It's good for a quick lunch! Relatively cheap too!
author: Bree G.

description: I just left La Tortilla. The whole place has to be in a dozen health code violations. For one, there was what looked to be a homeless man eating a burrito with his bare hands behind the counter. There was vomit on the ground. The bathroom also had vomit in it. My food was just okay, but will probably give me a stomach bug tomorrow. I feel disgusting. Next time, no thanks.
author: K M.

description:
When I'm drunk and/or hungry in the Castro, La Tortilla is the place to fill my tummy.

It's Mexican food that will fill my hungry and drunk desires.

The food is alright, nothing about it really blows my mind. I do appreciate that they're uber-vegetarian friendly, with a whole list of vegetarian items to choose from. I've had their veggie burrito, tacos, and mushroom burrito. It's a good place to go to get feed after a late night in the Castro.
author: Valerie L.

description:
I'm almost always pleased with my super veggie burrito. And it is damn hard to find a good burrito in this city, let me tell you. I consider myself a connoisseur. 

It might be a bit on the pricey side, but it's always a fatty and delicious burrito.
author: Inga B.

description:
I'm not really quite sure I get this. This is run by the same folks who own Casa Mexicana, which has always been a reliable, delicious, taqueria. They also own Mexico au Park, which my friends love. They also used to run Azteca, which, despite being a Casa Mexicana clone, was not as good. And now they have this place, which also isn't as good.

Things didn't taste very fresh. 

The open window is great for people-watching though, and the 80s music is great.

Then again, it's a mistake to look for good food on Castro street to begin with.
author: Mark A.

description:
You get a huge burrito for decent prices.  But mine fell apart as I was eating it.  And it had a strong taste of butter...Ick!  Despite being a tofu lover, I don't like it in my burrito, but they do offer it as a filling for those who do.

The high points are that it's a burrito joint on Castro (where taquerias are lacking), and that they're open late.  As I always say, I wouldn't doubt La Tortilla earning themselves an extra star if I came here inebriated.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I had the vegetable burrito. It was great! As in really, really good. I also really like that they give you a salsa bar you can re-visit at your leisure. I was stuffed by the time I finished. I thought prices were really good for what is probably a high-rent location. I will be back.
author: Nick F.

description:
Unfortunately, I'm quite harsh and hard on Mexican places. La Tortilla is not getting off easy. =)

This place is OK. Seriously, I pass by here and see that they've got the food all lined up to be assembled right in your face. Yeah, that's cool. I love it that I get to speak Spanish here, too. I don't get to do that often, really cool! =) 

This place really sucks at making food taste like food. I usually get the chorizo burritos or beans 'n rice burritos with carne asada. I get it that they don't include salsa in the burritos, hence the salsa bar. But, seriously, the beans, rice or meat have no flavor. A pinch of salt in the rice and meat would be really really nice. Every bite was filled with bland food. I was really disappointed. =( Adding tons of salsa somewhat fixes that, but really, there is no flavor.  The tortilla is also gross. It's steam heated, which is OK, but with every bite, your teeth get a layer of tortilla on it and you have to stop suck it out from between your teeth (forget it if you have braces!) then continue eating. I got sick of doing this and just tossed the burrito. Even in the fairly drunken state that I walked in, it still tasted flavorless and icky.

I really love Mexican food, but this place need some damn flavor. =(
author: Michael M.

description:
A tried and true favorite in the heart of the Castro... La Tortilla serves up Mexican favorites and house specialties. 

There is nothing better than a big bowl of their Pozole on a cold Sunday night (only made on the weekends) to warm the body and get you ready for another week. 

Great prices, friendly staff (that will even indulge you in speaking Spanish... or at least trying to speak Spanish), and generous portions make for a quick and easy meal when you don't have time to cook.
author: Jordan Y.

description:
In my ongoing attempt to find a Mexican restaurant that comes close to the epicness that is Freebirds of Isla Vista, I stumbled upon this little taqueria during one of my first visits to the Castro.

Boasting a wide selection of items to console even the grumbliest of tummies, you are sure to find something to feed your appetite. They even offer a complimentary bowl of chips just in case that super quesadilla with extra sour cream, beans, and guacamole didn't sufficiently subdue your hunger.
 
Overall, I had a pleasant first experience. The ladies working the food line were kind enough to put up with me ordering in my drunken pseudo-spanish dialect, the man working the cash register was benevolent enough to make a new burrito for the one that was now crudely splattered on the floor, and my new burrito was gracious enough to squirt its hot, greasy mess all over me when I took my first bite. Good times.

Although it doesn't compare to Freebirds, I will still visit La Tortilla from time to time for its quality and sheer convenience.
author: Matthew M.

description: Be prepared to have this place have nothing available on their menu. It doesn't seem to matter what time of day it is, they are always out of x and z. Worst part is that they will let you go down the list on what's on the menu only to end up telling you only one specific thing listed on the menu is available.When I've asked why they made me do that I've heard them make homophobic comments in Spanish as if I don't understand. Maricón, Joto, etc... And now tonight, besides being out of what I wanted, I ordered a Super Burrito but apparently they were out of cheese, sour cream and guacamole but rather then letting me know, they simply charged me full price for it rather than giving some kind of discount. I would avoid this place. They don't belong in the Castro if they can't deal with the queer neighborhood, let alone try and run a business without actually ever having what's on the menu be available.
author: Jim M.

description:
Like a couple of the other reviewers, recently a friend and I both felt sick and had stomach pains after eating here.  Of course, it could happen anyway, but when I looked up the health inspector's food score online it seemed to substantiate our concerns with "major violations" listed such as "inadequate cleaning facilities." http://www.cleanscores.com/rest-170611-La-Tortilla-San-Francisco

That aside, the food we had tasted ok.  It was a bit bland and uninspired, but it was good enough to eat.  The location is ideal, right on busy Castro Street and the service is actually very friendly.  I think if they clean up their act and work on the menu, they could turn things around.
author: Ryan L.

description:
There was a wait which was a good sign to me.  

I ordered a mushroom quesadilla.  They put lots of cheese which was nice, though it wasn't distributed very evenly so only the middle of the quesadilla got cheese, 1/3 from the edge to the middle was just tortilla.  It came with guacamole, which looked old: you know what I mean: the avocados in the guac had started to brown.  That is okay with homemade stuff, but when you do this for a living and sell it?  I would think they know the lemon juice trick for preserving the guacamole.

Regardless of that, the parts that had cheese, mushrooms and guac still tasted pretty good.  And it was freaking huge, I only had 1/3 of it and was full!  I think that you would really have to try hard to ruin a quesadilla and make it taste bad.  Even if the cheese was uneven throughout.  

I am curious to come back for the chorizo breakfast burrito.  I know, me and my chorizo.
author: Denise B.

description: Quick and easy place in the castro.  Food is pretty good and prices are decent
author: Jeremy G.

description: Just don't speak in Spanish to the staff if you want good service, because, regretfully, you'll be treated the way English speaking staff would treat the non-English speaking, which, to be clear, is unacceptable in any language to anyone. [It's a sad day when you have to speak in English to get good service in California. But, this is the place to do it.]
author: lorenzo h.

description:
After some bad luck at Zapata up the street, I was convinced that I would never find a decent burrito in the Castro. I probably never would have even tried La Tortilla had I not been lazy, but I was sure in for a surprise. 

I can generally judge a burrito by the first few bites, and right away I knew I had a winner, delicious rice, not too much beans, excellent all around. Of course, a burrito is more than just the first few bites, and if I must complain there were section of my burrito that were not proportioned correctly, 50% sour cream to everything else is just a little gross, as is 50% beans later on. But despite the inconsistencies I still enjoyed it because the ingredients were good. Not to mention their AWESOME salsa bar.

All in all, I'll probably still stick to my favorite places in the city, but this is definitely a burrito I would buy again, especially when I'm too lazy to go all the way to the mission.
author: Allyson S.

description:
I come to La Tortilla all the time. It's not that good. So why do I keep coming? Because I like the employees. I don't like like them; I just like them. I have grown to trust them for some reason.

It all started when I had to change buses at the corner of Castro and 18th. I couldn't very well eat Escape from New York Pizza three nights a week (although I'd love to), so I had to scope out another place. I didn't know about Zapata or El Castro at the time, so I hit up La Tortilla.

The place has a decent atmosphere inside. It's kind of Castroed up, but the copper ceiling is cool, and the burrito makers are as old school as you can get. For some reason, they're all women. I don't think I've ever seen a place like that before.

My biggest problem with this place is that the burritos fall apart. Every time. It's because they don't use foil and because they pack too much stuff in. And the tables are wobbly. But I'm being nitpicky. The tofu burritos are really really really good. Make sure you get black beans.
author: John S.

description:
Okay. The place has a bright color scheme and a promising menu with some Mayan dishes, as opposed to just standard taqueria offerings. My experience has been that this ends up being another mildly interesting variation on Mexican food,  rather than something distinct. 

I had a very good tamale there - wet and flavorful and home-made tasting.
author: Karsten P.

description: Delicious food, although it tended to unravel in my hand.  Messy but delicious.  The horchata agua fresca was so flavorful and a great compliment to the pork mole burrito.
author: Kameron H.

description:
...My lunch break today...

Tortilla lady: Hi, what would you like? 
Me: Hi, can I get the super veggie burrito.
Tortilla Lady: For here or to go?
Me: For here
Tortilla Lady: What kind of beans?
Me: Refried
Tortilla Lady: Everything on it?
Me: No salsa please
Tortilla lady #2: Anything to drink?
Me: Can I have a medium Diet Coke please

So, after I was given my to-go bag, I sat down to eat. I'm glad I decided to buy that Regular Coke, because I needed something to wash all the salsa down with.... are you getting the picture? They basically ignored everything I said aside from "veggie burrito", "refried" and "coke", and it was not at all busy at the time I went in.

They still get the three stars because this is the first time this has happened in the five or so times I've been. The food is always decent, and the staff are always polite, so I won't be a meanie. Not today, at least.

EDIT: I'm adding one more star for their Tofu Ranchero burrito. I'd been a little apprehensive about trying it, but I'm so glad I finally did. Tomatoey, salty, and yummy. I'm assuming I can substitute that in place of the meat in other items on the menu, like the tortas or tacos, and that makes me very very happy.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
La Tortilla has been there for me through thick and thin - whether I am too lazy too cook up a meal after work and looking for something filling and satisfying --- or as a drunken meal after having too many 2 for 1 drinks around the Castro - 

Moderately priced with big portions - the service is what brings me back.  Especially now that they know exactly what I want each time I come - is that I sign I should try a new burrito joint? Possibly, but for now - it fits the bill!
author: Wayne C.

description:
Walking in I noted the burrito bar had all the potential for a great burrito.  I ordered the defacto 'super burrito'.  My hopes shot up when my burrito barrista generously steamed the tortilla.  No cheese was added prior to the steaming process (ala ana's taqueria boston), but I was still hopeful.  I asked for everything served for here.  

Sitting down, I immediately took note that there was no tin foil wrapper to keep the delicious burrito mass warm.  Further, the tin foil was completely necessary because the epic fail of the burrito was half way through, it had fallen apart and I was forced to resort to a knife and fork.  A KNIFE AND FORK PEOPLE.  This is the sign of a bad burrito.  As far as the fix-ins went, the sour cream was too cold and chilled the burrito which caused a chain reaction for me.

I am going to give this place another shot.  The potential exists for greatness.  My strategy is to order to go next time.  That should guarantee a tin foil wrapper.  Perhaps the burrito barrista was having a bad day.  We shall see.
author: Parker W.

description:
I've been eating at this Taquerla for years, but today was my LAST TIME. As I looked to choose my meat EVERYTHING looked disgusting, at least the grilled chicken was full, so I assumed fresh. I am sitting here gagging right now GROSS. However, even after trying to eat this, the other stuff was even grosser. I should have said, "Uhh, sorry man, but this stuff all looks bad. I'm going somewhere else." 

As my stomach churns.. Adios, My mistake, but I will not be back again ever!
author: Jerry M.

description:
Conveniently located taqueria that is wisely open until 2 am.
This works in case you want to eat something postBadlands other than pizza or wallow forever in the underpar neighborhood dinners.

They have whole wheat tortillas but no brown rice. Their salsa is pretty unexciting but their chips are free of lard.
author: Sean S.

description:
So, the BF and I picked up burritos and nachos from here the other night.  We like the sister restaurant La Fonda in the Inner Sunset.

But this restaurant doesn't have the wide selection of meats that the Inner Sunset location has.  But they do have whole wheat tortillas (it just makes me feel sooo much better about eating a giant burrito).

I ended up getting the mole chicken burrito.  Rather, my boyfriend ended up getting me the mole chicken burrito (ww tortilla, black beans).  He also splurged and got us nachos (love nachos).  It was OK.  It was a lighter mole, and I like darker.  It was just kinda bland.

I really liked the nachos.  They're smothered in sour cream, guac, beans, and salsa.  My boyfriend didn't like their chips, which dropped his rating of the nachoes.

Also, their jalapenos aren't very good.  They're not spicy.  Actually, they don't really have any flavor.  And they're not even whole jalapenos.  They're julienned.  Boo.

In the end, I prefer La Fajita, which is just right around the corner on Market.
author: S J.

description:
For a late night filler-up in the Castro this is perfect. The prices are welcome in this otherwise wallet-demanding location and I actually enjoyed my veggie burrito a lot.

Another plus: service is very fast.

-
author: Alex C.

description:
Decent authentic mexican food.  We hit this spot for a buy one get one free burrito, which is a great deal for the 7 dollars you spend.

Order without lettuce or sour cream to avoid burritos being too wet.
Everytime we go, the food is good, and predictable.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
After witnessing a fight between a small gay man and a tall biological female (he bumped into her, she threw her drink in his face, he threw his drink in hers, she spit in his face, he grabbed her hair and pulled, they both slapped each other) at a nearby bar, my friend was hungry for a burrito.

So, he forced me to take a few bites of his post-binge drinking meal and I reluctantly agreed.  I remember this:  the tortilla was green and the biological girl from the fight was at the next table, wiping the vodka off her clothes.
author: Marcus C.

description:
La Tortilla is a great place to get a cheap burrito with cold, unmelted cheese, grab a seat and watch meth'd-out speedfreaks try to force down a few calories between bolts. The saving grace at La Tortilla is the spicy chicken: it isn't just hot for the sake of being hot, it has good flavor to it too.

But that bonus star brings La Tortilla up to just 3 stars for two reasons:

1) The atmosphere is decidedly whacked-out Castro ghetto-chic (hey, even the Castro has a pretty serious drugged-out downside), and if I want to eat surrounded by drunken, drugged-out idiots, there are lots of better burrito joints East of here to do so at, making LT only good for take-out, and...

2) The women working behind the counter can't seem to understand that melting the cheese in a burrito is a good thing. I don't know why, but they never melt the cheese in the burrito, meaning the cheese is always...unmelted. Which sucks. Seriously. 

There are few things worse than carrying home 8 lbs of burritos up the hills of Eureka Valley on foot, only to get home and find the cheese cold, unmelted, and glomming on to all the other now-cold ingredients.
author: Greg Q.

description:
Perhaps they like me? Or maybe my height intimidates them? I'm honestly not sure...

Every time I've been here, I've had delicious burritos.

And to stiffle those in the back...yeah, I know what a good burrito tastes like...I grew up in Stockton California.

I'm not saying this place is one of those "YOU HAVE TO VISIT ONCE IN YOUR LIFE" kinda places. But for what you pay for, it's pretty tasty. I'm a big fan of the super burritos with chicken. It's just how I roll. Add to that black beans, extra cheese, guac and avocado (with just a little bit of tomatoes and mild salsa) and you've got yourself my favorite thing to eat when I go there. Oh...and a Tamrind soda. THOSE are so good!

Seriously, check it out. And maybe if the people there are not nice (which I saw from one or two reviews) you should wonder if you're being nice to them. Oh yeah!
author: Nicolas H.

description: Decent Mexican food for an ok price. I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but I'm never disappointed.  Nothing fancy, but a solid choice.
author: Michael G.

description: I definitely came in here hungry and was disappointed.  I had a carne asada super burrito with all the trimmings and a small tazo de horchata.  Both were good, but definitely not on par with my favorite burrito place, La Morena.  Nothing special, but if you're in the Castro or stumbling home after a night of partying, stop by here and grab something for yourself if you've a hankering for some mexican food.
author: Ben T.

description: I had a super burrito. They're huge, but ehh, it tasted okay. I've had better from places in the Mission.
author: Laura D.

description: Ahhh the burrito was so flavorless and oddly textured.  I eat my fair share of burritos and this was the worst one I have had in a while.  The service was super fast and sweet though.  Maybe because the food was awful.  And the place was pretty empty...
author: Jonathan T.

description:
La Tortilla is an average gut-stuffer joint.  If you need to insert food into stomach, simply spend $7 here. They give me a merchant discount, which attracts me about once every 3 weeks or so.

I must say the one dinner that I really do enjoy is the Aztec-style burrito with mole sauce. Spicy red paprika sauce is poured over an entire burrito dinner, adding a tasty twist to a mexican favorite. Muy interesante (or whatever).
author: Daniel C.

description:
How better to prepare for a night with Gus Van Sant than to eat a burrito? conveintely located just doors away from the theater. The food is very inexpensive (speaking as a college student) and well worth it. That was quite a burrito! 
Pluses:
+ they got veggie options
+ beautiful eye candy :)
+  quickly made, and can be quickly eaten, if you're hunger enough
+ something for everyone

a little advice before you venture out: ask to get your burrito to be foil warpped... or you are in for an unattractive mess.
author: Melody S.

description:
Why is food in the Castro so awful! Why!?

Have come to this place a couple times, cumulative review. Not so great, but will do in a pinch. Bland, uninspired but appears to be clean and has good chips. 

The burristas are hurried and it was hard to tell if they were giving us the correct order since the burritos were not marked. Burrito anxiety! Yikes, do not trigger my finicky eater complex. I will flip out and make a scene.

On the plus side, they have breakfast burritos. The eggs are scrambled to order and the ham is in thick tasty chunks, not sad little lunch meat type of ham. And they have nopales. Delicious!
author: Krismet C.

description:
This place is ooookk.....but only ok. 
I've eaten here about 3 times. 2 out of the 3 experiences were bad. 
Once I ordered a regular burrito around 11 or 12 in the morning. It was steak, rice, beans and salsa. Without cheese it tasted hooorrible on top of that the steak was really chewy and tough, the beans tasted like they were slighty burned...like I got the scraped portion from the bottom of the pot or something. 
Another time I ate here I decided to give the quesadillas a chance....hmph....
So my quesadilla was really oily! dripping, as a matter of fact. Just a mess and disaster.
I had a chicken burrito with cheese my first time and it was good though, no complaints. Plus the staff seem....KIND OF...friendly but I can understand that they would be under alot of stress making food all day and being in the heat etc. So I'll give em a break.
author: Sueann W.

description: YUCK! I should have known from other reviews, but I thought the place looked super cute and colorful. My veggie burrito was COLD, no melted anything, and not even wrapped in foil. The salsas that were available were crappy and not spicy at all. Learned my lesson; only eat burritos in the Mission.
author: Theresa P.

description:
I'll give La Tortilla three stars.  That seems fair, much like my description of the food.  The service was great and the place seemed busy.  The prices were dirt cheap for The Castro.

The size of my burrito was definitely surprising... it was a two-hander.  Warning - the spicy chicken is REALLY spicy.  A friend also commented that his lips were burning.

Overall, not bad.  I stopped in a couple of days later for takeout and found the quality consistent, which I appreciate.
author: Brent R.

description:
I just don't know about this place.  I go here when I crave Mexican, and I am on my way to Muni, but I am always disappointed.  Everytime I go in and order something else, thinking that this is the day that I will love something from there and I will be a raving fan for the rest of my life.  But no.  Not yet.

The staff is nice enough and they have Coke in glass bottles that say "No Retornable" on it. 

Ah whatever.  I'll keep going there just because it's convenient but anyone else, with any other options...please utilize those.
author: Susan C.

description:
This place sucked the big one. Probably the worst Mexican food I've ever had. Tasted like a mushy nightmare that I tried to make better with hot, flavorless salsa. 

I was really excited to have nopales (cactus) and broccoli in a burrito, but la tortilla ruined it for me. SKIP this joint, ASAP.

The women were kinda bitchy too. The only thing I enjoyed were the people dressed as fairies sitting next to me.
author: Danielle K.

description:
Had a burrito here that was definitely worth the $6, plus chips and good salsa options, but overall not top quality. 

I liked the options- choose between four kinds of tortilla, three kinds of beans, four kinds of chicken (and other meats), five kinds of salsa. I went with an Azteca burrito, smothered in mole, guac, queso, and sour cream, all good but the mole was a bit sour. Overall the burrito was hot, fresh, and tasty, but I left wishing I had gotten the spicy chicken.
author: Cody E.

description: The Azteca Burrito. For eight bucks it's a mouthfull of burrito goodness. Good food with friendly, quick service.
author: Mrk P.

description:
Fast, inexpensive, tasty; friendly staff.  I come in almost once a week.  They might consider cleaning the seat cushions...
My favorite is the super taco.
author: Castro G.

description:
Good, reasonable Mexican food. They have the usual Mission-style burrito options. My favorite is the Azteca which is covered with sauce, cheese, guacamole and sour cream.

Service is pretty quick and there always seems to be a table or two if you want to eat in.  A couple of the ladies who work here are very nice.

This one is our choice in the Castro.
author: Michael M.

description: Love this place.  It's my new cure-my-hangover-now place.  Tacos are good, so are the chips and salsa they give you.  Ooh tried a tasty quesadilla too.  And the open windows and colorful decor make it fun.  This place can get crowded with rude drunks though, so be warned.  It's not the best mexican I've had by any means, but I like it a lot!
author: Aaron W.

description: $6 for a nice sized plate of huevos rancheros, beans and a side of 4 extra tortillas? Yes please.
author: Lux P.

description: Loved the corn tostada with chicken...yummy. Ate there almost every night and loved it. Must check it out if you like authentic Mexican.
author: Heather D.

description: Okay this place was awesome you know why? because its handicap friendly, I took my grandmother there to eat  after we had went to several other places in Castro to eat at but none were handicap friendly!!! I was like the wtf is there no gay handicap people around these parts or what? So La Tortilla came to the rescue and not only was it friendly place it also had great food! only thing I can complain about is I wish the AIR was on that day because it was hot! lol
author: amanda b.

description: I'll admit it, growing up in Seattle, I was never really exposed to truly good Mexican food. That said, I can spot BAD mexican food from a mile away (it's what I grew up with). Wandered in here late one night after imbibing a little too much....even in my I'm not picky and starving state...it was AWFUL. Tasteless. Even the guac and chips tasted like you know what.  I'm convinced they stay in business because of their location. And can they at least fix the damn sign???
author: Suepattra M.

description:
Okay. I hate to do this, but I have to:

I've been going to La Tortilla on average about 3 times per week for the past 4 years. I live in the Castro. I've always LOVED their chicken mole, and that's what keeps me coming back. Here's why I will never come back again:

I am fed up with their rude daytime service. 

The ladies who work at night are very pleasant and make their food with care. However, the woman making burritos during the day is AWFUL. Now, I don't expect to be treated with kid gloves at a taqueria and I know working with customers is hard (I've done it for years), but she always greets me with a nasty scowl when I smile and say hello, and that's if she'll even look at me at all! She slops the food on to the tortilla (which she often carelessly tears), and she is remarkably cheap on the meat portion (moreso than anyone else there). When I ask her for more meat, she tells me there will be an extra charge. And then she doesn't put any salsa on the burrito right after asking me, "Spicy or Mild?"

I've put up with this basic scenario for over a year, and I AM DONE. And if La Tortilla owners are reading, many of my friends have sworn you guys off because of "bad service." I'm sure this woman needs her job, but she is costing you loyal customers.
author: Christopher M.

description: 2.5 stars, rounding up.  The owner was friendly, but I found the food to be bland and somewhat overpriced.
author: She-Ra ..

description: My friend told me this place sucked, so whenever I hang out with him, we don't go here. But, last night, I was cold, hungry, lazy and this place was across the street and open. I got a super burrito with spicy chicken and hot salsa. The salsa was actually hot. It wasn't the best burrito I've ever had, but I thought it was good. The people who work there were extremely friendly and polite. I wasn't drunk, but I can imagine that it would be good drunk food. The burrito was huge, so I had my snack and lunch the next day. Works for me...
author: Veronica W.

description: This place was much better when it first opened.  It has slowly gone downhill over the years.  The last few times I ordered a burrito, the beans and meat were not even warm.  Also the staff can be very unfriendly at times.  I do think they have good carne asada and chicken mole.  The biggest issue is with the food not being warm enough and the lack of friendly service.  I truly hope they shape up.  I would hate to see another place in the neighborhood go out of business.
author: Russell C.

description: I've actually eaten here several times and have never been impressed.  The food is usually tasteless, though their refried beans on my last trip were pretty good.  The only reason I go back is because it's fun for people watching and a quick meal in the Castro.  Definitely don't come for the food!  Their Corona is very good though!  lol
author: Philip D.

description: Good burritos! I love how the salsa is actually spicy! Yum!
author: Mel P.

description: I could shit out better Mexican food. No offense to the Latin community, but La Tortilla is disgracing you.
author: James J.

description: Great tasting and very healthy veggie burrito (with broccoli, yeah!).  I think it may be the best veggie burrito in the city.
author: daniel g.

description: I went here on Sunday and ordered the Azteca chicken burrito.  Within 10 minutes after finishing I was so sick.  That day was horrendous.  It's Tuesday and I'm still under the weather.  This could happen at any restaurant, but for me it happened here...and I don't think I'll be returning.
author: Shaun J.

description: I have yet to try the famed broccoli burrito but I am a big fan of their shrimp burrito. It could stand to have more citrus flavoring but I love the roasted fajita veggies in it and everything tastes so fresh. Definitely reasonable prices, a great places for students to go as well as anyone craving fast Mexican food (service is speedy).
author: Rachel F.

description:
i am not impressed, but i am not unimpressed either.

totally average.

they forgot to put cheese in my burrito.  the interior is so colorful and cute.  

+ for having tofu.
author: paige m.

description: I had a pretty decent taco here one night before I headed over to the Castro theater.  I wish I had ordered t his Azteca burrito everyone's writing about.  Seeing as I love that theater I'll go back here the next time I catch a movie and update.
author: CAKE E.

description: Not bad, not good, just okay. I had two somewhat flavorless enchiladas with some rice that was half dry and flavorless as well. The service was good but not really anything worth writing home about. Not bad if you're needing a quick bite after too many beers.
author: Walter B.

description: We tried ths place despite the poor reviews. Big mistake. It really is horrible! The azteca burrito tasted like it was made with burnt dog food. The spicy prawns plate was under seasoned and the prawns were tiny. I would have been happier going to 7-11 for a burrito.
author: Sarah S.

description: For burritos, this is as good as it gets.  Though it might be surprising that their close neighbor, the Mission, is not home to the best burritos in San Francisco, it is true.  Let me count the ways.  1)  The meat (pollo asado, carne asada) is juicy and tasty.  2)  The rice is very flavorful, which makes even the vegetarian burritos delicious.  3)  The salsa bar boasts some of the best, fresh salsa that I have had.  4)  The large windows, open on a warm day, are relaxing an inviting.  5)  The staff is always responsive to customizing your burrito.  I always stop in when I am hungry and in the area.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
Such a bad visit, we made a video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ubWcy1Y3c7s
author: Eric V.

description: I was in the neighborhood and got a ham and juevos revueltos breakfast burrito. It was decent, but pretty plain, and we had to ask for salsa and chips. Horchata was a little gritty too. I live in the mission, so this place is not high at all on my list to go back to. Oh well.
author: Michael E.

description: I found the food here to be pretty good. The chips were fairly good for mass-produced tortillas, and the salsa was pretty spicy. The burritos were overly generous in size - I ate about 2/5 of my fajita burrito. The burrito was not too heavy on the rice - it contained plenty of meat and vegetables (green peppers and onions). The rice was done just right, as were the black beans. There may be better Mexican meals in the mission, but this place provides a fairly good experience. I found the staff to be fairly friendly. If only they could do something about the decor...
author: Dana L.

description: There weren't any people in costume when my husband and I had lunch there, and yes, the women behind the counter were bitchy to me, too, but it didn't matter...his mole was the best we've tasted in town.  Definitely coming back to try the other specials in this mexicatessen when in the neighborhood.
author: Holly B.

description: Another good and consistant low priced place to get mexican food in the castro...quick, clean friendly service :-)
author: Denny R.

description: Oh, this is the place I stumbled into after hitting the Bar.  Not memorable, but that's not necessarily a bad thing either.  The wait didn't suck, and the food didn't give me poisoning, plus it was open late, I think.
author: Sam N.

description: This is my "14 minutes til the next bus/I'm starving/pop in and grab dinner" burrito place.  It is much like the place up on 24th street, so that satisfies.  Nothing to write home about but gets me by on busy workweek night commutes home.
author: e w.

description: La Tortilla is great for a quick, cheap quesadilla or burrito. I also owe a slight debt to this place because for the last five years when I've worked at the Castro Street Fair they would let me come in and use the bathroom through out the day (I don't DO port-a-potties, okay?!).
author: Larisa S.

description: This place was alright.  I had a steak burrito which was quit tasty and BIG!  Prices are average and service was good.
author: L V.

description: Tasty veggie burritos for a mere $4.50 and open past 2am. My kinda place.
author: Kenny P.

description:
one of my favortie places. their spicy chicken is amazing!
plus they are open pretty late!
author: Ryan B.

description:
La Tortilla
Let me start by saying that their fire roasted red salsa in the little containers is The Bomb. I gave it 5 out of 5. The roasted veggies and jalapeo peppers were perfectly balanced. I could drink a pint and go home happy. I hope this just wasn't a good day for them and they can be as consistent the next time I go. In addition, I had 3 tacos. Tofu Tacos......Not grilled, you could tell it was stir fried and then soaked in a juice. Nothing special, I chose not to rate them and try them again later. Tacos Mole (Poblano).....If presentation was everything I'd give them a 5, but when I tasted the mole, I gave them a 2 out of 5.  It lacked a Chile flavor and the basic balance of sweet and savory every mole must have. Okay, the good new is that the carne asada is very good. I give it 4 out of 5. Perfectly grilled and seasoned, but could have been a bit juicer. I hate being so tough, but I wasn't a 5 at 2:00 pm. It's probably better at 11:00 am. 
The place is inviting. The decor and colors are nice, the order sequence (order before you pay) is also a plus, as well as the special attention you get from the food prep people. This all adds up and gives this Taqueira one up on the rest. Same goes for their healthy offerings, I plan on going back for more. Oh yeah, I dig the To-Go paper clam shell containers they use opposed to the Styrofoam just about at any restaurant on the planet uses. The other thing I like was the separate quesadilla station where one person just prepared quesadillas. Don't ask my why, it just looks like something I'd like to jump behind and help prepare.
author: Miguel V.

description: Solid, standard burritos.  Same deal as Mexico au Parc by where I used to work, which was my favorite lunch spot.  Definitely worth hitting up for a quick burrito, but it's nothing mind blowing.  I dig their tostadas or the basic burrito.  Free chips and salsa always appreciated.  Also, if you order chips and salsa to go you get a tub bigger than you'd get at the store for pennies.  Great deal.
author: Nate R.

description: The service was great but the fish and shrimp tacos were the worst I've ever had. The rest of the food might be great but these tacos were overpriced and gross. The tacos were so wet that I couldn't pick them up and could barely eat them with a fork. The shrimp were those tiny pink Bay shrimp about as big as a quarter and totally flavorless. The fish was also flavorless. The other stuff on the taco was a small mix of shredded iceberg and salsa. Also no texture and no flavor. This is the first bad review I've ever given a place but really, these were disgusting and I won't go here again. I had to eat some Hot Cookie to get the taste out of my mouth. Nice people, great location, nasty overpriced tacos.
author: Mia F.

description: Pretty so so food even by taqueria standards the only reason I'd even think of going here again is because of the sit in widow.
author: Kris J.

description: Friendly staff (though I got into it with some lady worker a few years back only cause she assumed I didn't speak spanish, love it!) and good food. I love it here when its noon or 1:30am cause they are open that late on Fridays and Saturdays. I usually get a regular burrito with chicken mole or on a sunny day their chicken ceasar with the honey ceasar paired with a Corona will hit the spot.
author: Allen B.

description: I've eaten at this place twice and I've had mixed experiences. The first time I ate here I got the Chile Relleno dinner and it was pretty good, a heaping serving with beans, rice and chips for under $8. I ate here again yesterday with my girlfriend and I ordered a grilled fish taco. I was disappointed that it was salmon, I was expecting white fish, and there was no special sauce on it to speak of so it was rather plain. The chips on the second visit were also hard and undercooked. On the bright side, the interior is cute and colorful and it's kind of fun sitting in the corner by the window with the high cushioned seats - although be aware of the precariously wobbly table. Also, the prices are great. Two meals for under $9, a great place to eat before or after a screening at the nearby Castro Theater.
author: Kabochan Y.

description: People, don't be fooled by the colorful and perfect Castro location! The food in this place is DISGUSTING!!! It's almost as if it's recycled. The other day I bought a carnitas burrito and the meat tasted like rubber. Yuck! I wonder if they recycle the food others leave behind. It's gross! Gross! Gross! This restaurant MUST go out of business!! There are SO MANY other good businesses that can take its place. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY buying Mexican food at La Tortilla in the Castro! You will regret it! They give Mexican food a very, very bad name!!
author: Enrique C.

description: Consistently yummy chicken mole burritos, good salsa, friendly staff, and fun window seats to watch the crowds go buy make this the best burrito place in the Castro (much better than La Fajita... Zapata is pretty good & maybe more authentic, but not as yummy).   Just make sure you have them wrap your burrito in foil even if you're eating in... they'll fall apart otherwise.
author: SFSuperstar A.

description: This is my favorite places to get a wet burrito. The Azteca Burrito is huge and delicious. They are friendly and the place is nice. Especially if you can sit at the window and people watch. I tend to be too distracted by my burrito...
author: Damon K.

description:
great place for a date,
they'll get your food right and it will be tasty,
you'll be full by the end and ready to saunter around Castro with your sweetheart.

i'm a straight female and the burritos here are so good they can always get my boyfriend to make this trip to the castro.

another bonus here is that the BURRITOS ARE GIANT! i usually get another meal/snack out of the left over half i wrap up and take with me after gorging myself.
author: Carolyn W.

description: This is just an ok place to grab a quick burrito when you're too lazy to walk over to the Mission. The burritos are acceptable -- not fantastic flavor but not terrible either. The evening staff are friendly. On occasion they'll get an order wrong, under cook meat, or destroy your burrito in the process of rolling it, but generally the food is decent. The prices are a bit high for Mexican.
author: Scott Z.

description: I've only recently been going to this place, but I think that the value is good here. I used to go to Zapata's a block away, but I think the food here is better.
author: J M.

description: needed a burrito fix after 11pm last night after skipping dinner to go to the bay area derby girls league championship.  while i knew a burrito in the mission would be much better, this was more on my way home.  i got a super veggie burrito which filled me up but was not actually tasty and fairly cold.  the chips tasted old.  wouldn't go back -- too many good mexican places around.  but thanks for filling the burrito-shaped hole in my tummy.
author: micaela r.

description: Bland and might go back if I'm in the need of something to soak up late night alcohol.
author: Scott H.

description: On a tuesday night, we were too tired and lazy to cook dinner, and too tired and lazy to look decent enough to go to an actual restaurant, so we swung around the corner to la tortilla. ive walked past it a billion times. i dont usually eat at counter type places. its not really fast food, but the ingredients are out already. they looked gross. but j had eaten there before and he said id like it and hes picky and so i went on his word. it was good. i got an azteca burrito, because it has the most stuff.  it was $6 something i think. or 7. i forget. not spectacular but it was good, better than i expected. plenty of food - i was full. the chips that came with it were a little dry. j got the same thing. n and s got regular buritos, which they liked too. people were normal nice, not too nice and not rude. the mexican soda was good, very sweet. we ate in, and left when someone was stinky in the bathroom which we happened to be sitting next to. id go back, esp since it closes at 2am now. its cheaper and more food than the diners around there. just dont expect gourmet or anything.
author: Merredith L.

description: Rice in burritos just seems wrong to me.  Best part about the restaurant was watching the nuts outside.
author: Phil M.

description: This place is disgusting.  I went in there at 10 PM on a weeknight (they are open until 11:00 PM) and ordered a chicken burrito.  It was totally room temperature.  When I complained, the rude clerk threw it in the microwave, and when I told her I'm concerned about food safety, i.e. keep hot food hot, she threw it in the garbage and then refused to give me a refund.  Now I don't expect a red carpet when I go into a taqueria, and I already knew this place was average at best, but this was over the top.  I think it's truly unhealthy!
author: Jim W.

description: I love this place. The food is pretty cheap, the staff is really nice and nothing beats sitting in the windows on a sunny day, people -watching. The burritos are massive and for tacos they give enough food to make double the number ordered.
author: Michael G.
